Sure, one example of how data analytics has been used to improve sustainability in manufacturing is through energy management systems (EMS). These systems use sensors and data analytics software to track energy consumption in real-time, identify areas of inefficiency, and provide actionable insights to reduce energy usage.

For instance, General Motors (GM) used data analytics to optimize the energy usage in one of their manufacturing plants in Ohio. By implementing an EMS and collecting real-time data, they were able to identify areas where energy was being wasted and found that a significant amount of energy was being consumed during unoccupied periods. They were then able to adjust heating, ventilation, and air conditioning settings during these periods, resulting in a 52% reduction in energy usage.

Furthermore, data analytics has also been helpful in waste reduction. One study conducted by researchers at the University of Melbourne found that data analytics can be used to reduce food waste in manufacturing. Based on data collected from sensors and databases, predictions can be made on the amount of food that may potentially go to waste. Manufacturers can use this data to plan production more efficiently to minimize food waste.

These examples show how data analytics can be used to improve the sustainability and efficiency of manufacturing processes. By using data to drive insights about inefficiencies, manufacturers can make informed decisions to reduce waste, optimize energy consumption, and minimize their environmental footprint.
